title: Ticket #6935: Unexpected exceptions in Python bindings
description:
The Python bindings often raise Python exceptions which are not consistent with the way the rest of the community uses them.

Here are the patterns I saw:

- usage of RuntimeError (or sometimes ValueError!) when unable to do stuff with another host/process/daemon

Any sort of communication error is an IOError. It would be even better to make one or more subclasses of IOError for different categories of problems so people can distinguish them without having to parse text.

- usage of SyntaxError or RuntimeError when there is a problem parsing a classad

SyntaxError is reserved for Python syntax errors. For classad parsing errors, make a new classad.ParseError exception.

- usage of TypeError or ValueError (often inconsistently) when failing to evaluate expressions

Better to make an EvaluateError (classad.EvaluateError?) instead so people can tell it's a problem with their classad.

- usage of ValueError when an object is not iterable

This is pretty clearly a TypeError.

- usage of RuntimeError at all

RuntimeError is too generic; it leads to people parsing the error message to figure out what the actual problem is, which we don't want.

A couple of other problems (files and line numbers are from src/python-bindings in master (8a4c7f9ad6)):

bulk_query_iterator.cpp

lines 122-125: 
if (m_selector.failed())
{
    THROW_EX(RuntimeError, "select() failed.");
}
select() failing is probably an OSError especially if it has an errno associated with it.

classad.cpp

line 526: 
if (!PyObject_HasAttrString(source.ptr(), "__iter__")) THROW_EX(ValueError, "Must provide a dictionary-like object to update()");
Use TypeError.

config.cpp

lines 245, 580: 
if (!py_hasattr(source, "__iter__")) { THROW_EX(ValueError, "Must provide a dictionary-like object to update()"); }
TypeError.

JobEventLog.cpp

line 53: 
THROW_EX( RuntimeError, "deadline must be an integer" );
TypeError.
remarks:
2019-Mar-02 20:34:35 by tlmiller: 
> Here are the patterns I saw:
>
> - usage of RuntimeError (or sometimes ValueError!) when unable to do stuff with
> another host/process/daemon
>
> Any sort of communication error is an IOError.

Just to be certain: it's an IOError to specify a host which doesn't exist?

> It would be even better to make one or more subclasses of IOError for
> different categories of problems so people can distinguish them without
> having to parse text.

....

> - usage of ValueError when an object is not iterable
>
> This is pretty clearly a TypeError.

Implying that when object.__iter()__ returns an object which doesn't have an iterator, it's also a TypeError?

Does code like the following make sense? 

if (m_claim.empty()) {THROW_EX(ValueError, "No claim set for object.");}

Would it make more sense to return a failure, instead? Likewise, claim.cpp is lousy with: 

// FIXME: Should at least be IOError
THROW_EX(RuntimeError, "Startd failed to activate claim.");

but IOError seems a little ill-fitting -- the IO succeeded, but the command in question did not. That seems like maybe the function should return success or failure and only throw IOError if something actually happened to the I/O?

2019-Mar-03 13:09:17 by tlmiller:
Is there a reason that _classad_module.cpp and _htcondor_module.cpp exist? (Can we really not bully CMake into making different libraries out of the same source file?) Is there a reason that they aren't symlinks? (It would seem to violate the principle of least astonishment for the wheel-built modules to be different.)

2019-Mar-04 11:42:47 by matyas:
  > Just to be certain: it's an IOError to specify a host which doesn't exist?
Yes. For example, the built-in "socket" library throws "socket.gaierror" (https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/socket.html#socket.gaierror), which is descended from IOError.

  > Implying that when object.__iter()__ returns an object which doesn't have an iterator, it's also a TypeError?
I'm not sure what you mean here. object.__iter__() should return an object that is an iterator. If the object is not iterable (e.g. an integer), then it shouldn't have __iter__() defined at all. Python will raise a "TypeError" is you attempt to get an iterator of a non-iterable object (i.e. "iter(object)").

  > if (m_claim.empty()) {THROW_EX(ValueError, "No claim set for object.");}
This is the kind of place where a custom exception would be handy -- a ClassadError or something. For example, the built-in "json" library raises "JSONDecodeError" on a parse error; JSONDecodeError is a subclass of ValueError with additional attributes for the line and column number of the parse error. 

    // FIXME: Should at least be IOError
    THROW_EX(RuntimeError, "Startd failed to activate claim.");
  > but IOError seems a little ill-fitting -- the IO succeeded, but the command in question did not. That seems like maybe the function should return success or failure and only throw IOError if something actually happened to the I/O?
What's more important here is that the error happened in another program. For example, the built-in "urllib2" library raises HTTPError, which is descended from IOError, if the remote server returns a 404.

If an error is fairly common and usually survivable, you may want to add a way to bypass it -- that's when you return success/failure, or a default value, or something.

2019-Mar-06 14:21:13 by tlmiller:
Design doc:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1K0LYRgorNlEVuXQGliT_zPnijCPdjbEPZuXj--CIBr0

Document does not cover how we'll release the changes, which probably depends on another discussion about versioning the bindings.

2020-May-21 17:12:49 by karpel:
Necro'ing this ticket because it got brought up in the APIs session at HTCondor Week 2020. We have a user doing exactly what Mat warned would happen: they are parsing the message of the RuntimeError generated when an edit fails to modify any ads to differentiate it from, say, the RuntimeError that gets generated when you fail to contact the schedd.

@ToddM, is there anything blocking progress on this, or did we just lose track of it? Looks like a lot of code got written, but it's been rotting off on a branch.

2020-May-21 17:19:21 by tlmiller:
I don't recall any particular code blockers, but without a good way to introduce the changes, this wasn't a high-enough priority to work on.

2020-Jul-07 10:49:05 by tlmiller:
Two new proposals:

(1) Temporarily make the new exceptions sub-classes of the old ones. (2) Add a 'version-of-interface' flag to choose which exceptions are thrown.

The benefit of (1) is not breaking old code, and simplicity. The disadvantage is that users could easily not notice the deprecation until it's too late.

For (2), we could make the default the new behavior, and require the user to opt-in to the old behavior. This has the advantage of making sure the user knows abut what's going on, and it also handles API changes other than just exceptions. Obviously, we could instead make the default old rather than new. The problem here is potentially -- especially if old is the default -- breaking old behavior because of complicated interactions in the code. That might be one benefit of having new be the default (meaning, expect things to break).

2020-Aug-27 12:23:02 by karpel:
Code Review

ToddM went with the "make the new errors subclasses of the existing errors" approach. This has introduced a lot of wackiness into the inheritance hierarchy of our exceptions, but I think this is unavoidable for backwards compatibility. I am comfortable with this tradeoff.

Basic structure of the changes look good. I like the writeup detailing the logic of implementation a lot. I would perhaps include some notes on what each of the exceptions mean in plain text, or as docstrings of the exceptions themselves if that's possible in Boost. We should write down and agree on the meanings of the exceptions to avoid getting back into a situation like we're trying to dig out of right now.

Some exceptions are troubling, like THROW_EX(HTCondorAssertionError, "Logic error in poll implementation.");, which seems like it indicates a gap in our understanding of the failure case. Maybe it can just be an HTCondorInternalError?

There are a few places that something like THROW_EX(ClassAdEvaluationError, "Unable to evaluate expression"); happens; it would be nice if we could get a more detailed error message in, but I don't think that's a blocker for this ticket.

I'm suspicious of THROW_EX(ClassAdTypeError, "Unable to iterate through ads."); in classad.parseOne - that seems like it should maybe be some kind of ValueError, or ClassAdParseError? Similar construction in other parsing functions should also be looked at.

THROW_EX(HTCondorNotImplementedError, "Startd-with-ack protocol is not implemented at this time."); I am ok with plain `NotImplementedError` for this.

I would maybe call HTCondorEnumError something like HTCondorInvalidEnumMember to make it more specific. In general, exception don't need to be *Error... though I don't think there are really better names for most of these. One could argue between HTCondorLocateError and e.g. FailedToLocateDaemon; I don't think it matters much.

2020-Aug-27 14:46:59 by tlmiller:
(Responses in order of the code review.)

  • [61126] added a draft of the usage guidelines, which got reviewed before being turne into actual documentation in [61138], which added docstrings and the corresponding sections in the manual.

  • [61125] eliminated HTCondorAssertionError.

  • [61127] corrected the exceptions in parseOne() and parseNext().

  • [61123] eliminated HTCondorNotImplementedError.
